references: Utilizing this generation method, we create a virtual character dataset named           Human Simulacra          , comprising about 129k texts across 11 virtual characters. Basic statistics are presented in Table                  1                .

references: Self-report assessments are designed to evaluate the simulacra’s ability to establish self-awareness, testing their memory and analytical capabilities regarding their character information. Table                  2                presents the results of self reports, with all outcomes being the average of three repeated tests.

Based on the data presented in Table                  2                , we have the following observations: 1) even without any knowledge of the target character, the LLMs can still score certain points (6 out of 50) on these single- or multiple-choice questions by random guessing. This indicates that relying solely on these questions for evaluation is not sufficiently reliable; 2) as the size of LLMs’ parameters increases, the capability of LLMs gradually enhances, leading to a clearer self-awareness and an upward trend in self-report scores; 3) since the self-report test is conducted in a conversational manner, the LLMs fine-tuned for conversational scenarios tend to perform better (e.g., Llama-2-13b and Vicuna-13b-v1.5); 4) while the RAG-based simulacra can retrieve detailed and relevant life story chunks when answering questions, their performance is constrained by the LLMs’ information processing capacities. A large amount of descriptive information may interfere with the LLMs’ self-positioning, resulting in inappropriate responses or misunderstanding of questions. Hence, in most weaker-performing LLMs, RAG-based simulacra score lower than Prompt-based ones; 5) In stronger-performing LLMs like GPT-4 and GPT-4-Turbo, with the help of emotional and logical analysis, the MACM-based simulacra achieve the best results in all tests (44 out of 50 points). However, the effectiveness of the MACM method remains constrained by the LLMs’ analytical capabilities.

id_table_3.caption: Observer reports of different simulacra on GPT-4-Turbo.
table: Method Description Matching Score Response Similarity Score Final Score 7 Judge 3 Judge 4 Average Judge 1 Judge 2 Average Prompt 14.25 18.50 16.38 19.50 17.00 18.25 34.63 RAG 20.50 17.00 18.75 14.00 14.00 14.00 32.75 MACM 17.50 18.00 17.75 20.50 21.50 21.00 38.75
references: Experimental results from Table                  3                indicate that while the RAG-based simulacra perform well on the self-report tests when compared to the Prompt-based ones, the retrieved story segments do not significantly enhance the simulacra’s ability to accurately mimic their target character’s personality, thoughts, and actions. In contrast, the MACM-based simulacra not only extract context-relevant, emotionally and logically rich memory fragments from long-term memory but also conduct divergent analysis for the current situation. During observation, the MACM-based simulacra better reflect thoughts and behaviors consistent with their target character’s personality, achieving more authentic simulations from the inside out.
